events.originalText: FDA approval of exagamglogene autotemcel, the first CRISPR gene editing therapy to be approved.
events.subtitle: Exagamglogene autotemcel
events.headline: FDA approves exagamglogene autotemcel as first CRISPR gene editing therapy

events.originalText: After a fatal car accident in the Little India region of Singapore, angry mobs of passers-by attacked the bus involved and emergency vehicles, the first riot in the country in over 40 years.
events.subtitle: Little India, Singapore
events.headline: Fatal car accident in Little India sparks riot in Singapore

events.originalText: The Japanese experimental spacecraft IKAROS (model pictured) flew by Venus at a distance of 80,800 km (50,200 mi), completing its planned mission to demonstrate solar-sail technology.
events.subtitle: IKAROS
events.headline: Japanese spacecraft IKAROS completes mission, flies by Venus

events.originalText: Bombings in Baghdad carried out by the Islamic State of Iraq killed at least 127 people and injured at least 448 others.
events.subtitle: December 2009 Baghdad bombings
events.headline: Islamic State bombings in Baghdad kill 127, injure 448

events.originalText: The Australian Cricket Board's cover-up of Shane Warne and Mark Waugh's involvement with bookmakers was revealed.
events.subtitle: Cricket Australia
events.headline: Australian Cricket Board cover-up scandal revealed

events.originalText: Belarusian, Russian and Ukrainian leaders signed the Belovezh Accords, agreeing to dissolve the Soviet Union and establish the Commonwealth of Independent States.
events.subtitle: Belovezha Accords
events.headline: Belarus, Russia, Ukraine sign Belovezh Accords, dissolve Soviet Union

events.originalText: A man shot and killed eight people at the Australia Post building in Melbourne, before jumping to his death.
events.subtitle: Queen Street massacre
events.headline: Eight killed in shooting at Australia Post building in Melbourne

events.originalText: Arab–Israeli conflict: An Israeli army tank transporter killed four Palestinian refugees and injured seven others during a traffic accident at the Erez Crossing on the Israel–Gaza Strip border, sparking the First Intifada.
events.subtitle: Arab–Israeli conflict
events.headline: Israeli tank transporter accident sparks First Intifada

events.originalText: English musician John Lennon  was murdered at the entrance of the Dakota, his residence in New York City.
events.subtitle: John Lennon
events.headline: John Lennon murdered at Dakota residence in New York City

events.originalText: During an aborted landing and go-around while approaching Chicago's Midway International Airport, United Airlines Flight 553 crashed into a residential neighborhood, destroying five houses and killing forty-five people.
events.subtitle: Go-around
events.headline: United Airlines Flight 553 crashes near Chicago, killing 45

events.originalText: After being struck by lightning while in a holding pattern, Pan Am Flight 214 crashed near Elkton, Maryland, U.S., killing all 81 people on board.
events.subtitle: Holding (aeronautics)
events.headline: Pan Am Flight 214 crashes in Maryland after lightning strike, killing 81

events.originalText: The Holocaust: The Chełmno extermination camp in occupied Poland, the first such Nazi camp to kill Jews, began operations.
events.subtitle: The Holocaust
events.headline: Chełmno extermination camp begins operations in occupied Poland

events.originalText: At an assembly of 10,000 Boers, Paul Kruger announced the fulfilment of the decision to restore the government and volksraad of the South African Republic.
events.subtitle: Boers
events.headline: Paul Kruger announces restoration of South African Republic government

events.originalText: Pope Pius IX (pictured) promulgated the apostolic constitution Ineffabilis Deus, proclaiming the dogmatic definition of the Immaculate Conception, which holds that the Virgin Mary was conceived free of original sin.
events.subtitle: Pope Pius IX
events.headline: Pope Pius IX proclaims Immaculate Conception dogma

events.originalText: American Revolutionary War: British commander-in-chief Sir William Howe withdrew his troops from the Battle of White Marsh to Philadelphia.
events.subtitle: American Revolutionary War
events.headline: British commander Howe withdraws troops from Battle of White Marsh

events.originalText: Margaret Hughes appeared professionally on the English stage; she is thought to have been the first woman to do so.
events.subtitle: Margaret Hughes
events.headline: Margaret Hughes first woman to appear professionally on English stage
